awd_abstract_narration:
The questions under study in this research project are central to an area of mathematics known broadly as extremal combinatorics, which develops tools to classify and analyze mathematical structures in which certain substructures are forbidden. A typical question asks for the classification of graphs with a maximum number of edges that do not contain certain subgraphs. The mathematical theory behind such questions is at the foundation of many areas of mathematics, including combinatorial number theory and geometry. Applications are found in diverse areas of science, including theoretical computer science, coding and cryptography, algorithmic complexity, as well as other areas of mathematics. Extremal structures are particularly valuable in the construction of error-correcting codes. This project explores innovative approaches to the theory, whereby an original question is embedded in a geometric setting and the imposed geometry is used to obtain additional information. The project includes training of graduate students through their involvement in the research.

This project concerns research in combinatorics, focusing on Turan-type extremal problems and applications. By exploring the connection between pure Turan-type problems and other areas of mathematics, the project aims for new insights to solve some important open problems. Such connections have resulted in recent success, such as the polynomial method for breakthroughs on the mathematical cap set problem, a Turan-type problem closely related to the complexity of multiplication of two square matrices, which is at the heart of many practical applications. In this project, some new approaches are explored, whereby we embed a Turan type problem in a geometric setting, and then use the imposed geometry to obtain information regarding the original problem. This approach has been particularly effective in recent work for certain well-known hypergraph Turan problems. The researcher plans to employ some of the most recent mathematical tools, including probabilistic and polynomial methods, to solve some central problems in the area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal focuses on topics the area of combinatorics, with particular attention to extremal-type problems for graphs and hypergraphs, Ramsey theory, and probabilistic methods. The mathematical theory behind these problems is key to applications to other areas of science, including coding theory, pseudorandomness and algorithms, statistical physics and theroetrical computer science, and is strongly connected to other areas of mathematics.  With the support of this award, the PI and coauthors made substantial advances in extremal graph and hypergraph theory, Ramsey theory and on pseudorandom graphs. 

Extremal problems involve classifying and analyze mathematical structures in which certain substructures are forbidden. A typical problem asks for the classification of graphs with a maximum number of edges -- so-called extremal graphs -- that do not contain certain subgraphs. An example of research on such problems supported by the award include problems on paths in graphs and on intersecting families. Classical theorems of Erdos and Gallai from the 1950s determine this maximum when the forbidden subgraph is a path, and with the support of this award, a number of papers have been published classifying not only the extremal graphs but also establishing stability, which specifies the structure of near-extremal graphs. Regarding intersecting families, the well-known theorems of Erdos-Ko and Rado and Hilton and Milner from the 1960s consider the extremal problem for subsets of size $r$ in a finite set $X$, no two of which are disjoint. Such a family of sets is called non-trivial if no element of $X$ is contained in all of them. In 1967, Hilton and Milner conjecture the maximum number of subsets in a non-trivial family where any $d$ of the sets intersect, and this problem was completely solved by the PI and a supported research student with this award. With this award, the PI and coauthors also made advances and published a number of papers on a new  connection between Ramsey theory and pseudorandom graphs, and problems in combinatorial geometry via convex geometric graphs and hypergraphs.
